Irene Davis is the founding Director of the Spaulding National Running Center at the Harvard Medical School. In this episode, Irene describes how her research of biomechanics and clinical work with running injuries, as well as research by others, has shaped her views on maintaining body alignment and foot health. Irene discusses her argument for the role of modern footwear in running-related injuries and how minimalist footwear helps resolve the subsequent biomechanical issues.

	Episode Details

View the Show Notes Page for This Episode  Become a Member to Receive Exclusive Content  Sign Up to Receive Peter’s Weekly Newsletter In this episode, Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D., discusses the widespread impact of stress on our physical and emotional health as well as the mechanisms by which it can precipitate chronic illness, dementia, depression, and more. He also provides insight into the factors that contribute to the stress response (and our ability to handle it) such as social rank, personality, environment, and genetics. Lastly, we discuss how our behavior is altered in the face of stress and how that not only has a pervasive effect on a personal level, but also on society as a whole in how we interact with each other. We discuss:  Background, interest in stress, and Robert’s time in Kenya studying baboons [2:45]; Physiology of a stress response, and why it’s ingrained in our DNA [9:45]; Individual variation in the response to stress, and how everyone has a different optimal level [19:45]; How social rank and personality differences affect our stress response [26:30]; What’s happening in the brain when faced with stressful situations? [35:00]; What makes the human brain different than all other species? [44:15]; Imprinting stress to your kids epigenetically [48:00]; The role of stress on memory and the consequences of hypercortisolemia [53:00]; The impact of subjective socioeconomic status and social media on stress levels and health [57:45]; Tips for managing stress in the modern world [1:13:15]; What Robert learned about himself studying the social behavior of baboons [1:25:30]; The multilayered factors behind every human behavior, the context of “good and bad”, and exploring the human capacity of the wild extremes of violence and altruism from moment to moment [1:30:15]; PMS: How two women with identical hormone levels can have completely different emotional experiences [1:34:45]; How much of a role do genes play in depression and other emotional states? [1:38:00]; Why is cortisol elevated under sleep deprivation? [1:46:00]; The impact of stress on cancer [1:50:30]; The impact of stress on atherosclerosis, dementia, addiction, and depression [1:57:00]; Impulsiveness, impaired judgment, and lack of empathy in times of stress [2:01:45]; What advice would Robert give his 25-year-old self? [2:08:45]; and More.  Connect With Peter on Twitter, Instagram, Facebook and YouTube

            Show NotesIrene’s path to her Ph.D., her entry into physical therapy, and her interest in biomechanics [3:20]
The path to and focus of Irene’s Ph.D.

She originally wanted to be in the FBI, but at the time, women weren’t allowed
Classes in exercise science eventually led her to completing a degree in physical therapy
Her curiosity led her to complete a master’s degree and Ph.D. in biomechanics 
She completed her Ph.D. at Penn State under Dr. Peter Kavanaugh, who is a pioneer of running mechanics

Irene’s early work as a physical therapist

Watching her cousin go through physical therapy after being paralyzed in a car accident inspired her to become a physical therapist herself
She started her physical therapy career in spinal cord rehab
After starting graduate school, she shifted to outpatient physical therapy

What shifted Irene’s interest towards biomechanics

Quadriplegics need to move their entire body with just 25% of their muscle – they need to learn to use their bodys in atypical ways

 
How Irene’s thinking about the use of orthotics has changed [7:15]
Early in Irene’s career, she was a proponent of orthotics

She prescribed orthotics as a physical therapist
She taught about orthotics at the University of Delaware
She simply believed that some people had feet that were incapable of supporting themselves

Irene’s thinking began to change based on her research and when the book Born to Run was published

Her research led her to realize that people who land on their heels while running incur greater impact forces, and that footwear influences these forces
This, plus the message in book Born to Run, made her reflect on the traditional approach of physical therapy for other areas of the body – removing support to encourage patients to improve their intrinsic ability
The permanent nature of orthotics is the opposite of this approach
Irene says, “And it kind of brought me back to when I was a physical therapist in rehab, where we would try to take away as much support and bracing to our patients, even wheelchairs, a lower back, less lower extremity bracing so that they would use what they had. And yet my thinking in terms of feet was completely opposite. … We don’t brace anything else permanently if you have an orthopedic problem.”

Despite the common thinking that we should be prescribing a shoe type based on an individual’s need for support, a study done by Joe Knapik on thousands of military personnel found that there was no difference in injury rate
 
The evolution of the human foot and the transition from walking to running [10:30]
Anatomical changes from walking man (Australopithecus) to running man (Homo erectus)

A study by Dan Lieberman and Dennis Bramble (Bramble & Lieberman, 2004) describes human evolution in the context of endurance running
Joint surfaces became larger to bear greater forces
The longitudinal and medial longitudinal arches developed
The achilles tendon became longer for greater energy storage


Figure 1. The longitudinal arch and bony structure of the foot. Image credit: oist.jp
Complexity of the foot

The foot has 26 bones, 33 articulations, and six degrees of freedom, resulting in a complex structure
It has four layers of arch muscle comprised of 10 muscles

This complexity allows for a stable base of support while being able to adapt to uneven terrain and absorb shock

The “born to run” concept

Peter recalls Dan Lieberman stating during a lecture that no animal can cover as great of a distance over 24 hours as a human
Humans have been running for 2 million years 
The ability to run greater distances was an evolutionary advantage that allowed our ancestors to chase larger animals to exhaustion

 
The evolution of shoes and its impact on running injuries [17:30]
Earliest shoes

The earliest known shoes date back to 10,000 years ago
They were made with sage brush bark and were basically a flat surface with a strap, similar to Huarache sandals
The primary purpose was to protect the bottom of the foot

Early running shoes

Prior to the 1960s, running footwear was similar to what is sold as minimalist shoes today
As running became a popular activity for the general population, people were getting injured

Achilles tendonitis was common — the general population were used to walking around in shoes with a slightly raised heel
Then when the running boom happened, the existing running shoes were flat (i.e., no heel raise)
At that point, new running shoes were created with a heel lift and cushioning in an attempt to counteract the injuries



Types of modern running shoes

“Motion control” shoes have a very stiff heel counter and stiffer material in the mid sole. They may also have additional plastic reinforcement, all to prevent the foot from rolling in
“Cushioning” shoes are for people with a high arch and little foot movement
Running injuries did not appear in the research literature, or at least not nearly as much, until approximately when these specialized shoes appeared. 

 
An overview of running injuries [26:00]

Running injuries are most commonly from the knee down, but can go all the way up to the neck
The reason why most injuries occur from the knee down is because this is where most shock absorption occurs

Landing incurs a force that is 2.5 to 3 times body weight
At the knee, this force can be 7 times body weight


According to Jeff Johnson, a former Nike employee, Nike brought in three sports podiatrists who concluded that the rise in running injuries was due to too much impact and motion, leading towards the added motion control and cushioning that is now seen in running shoes

“Rather than have the runners adapt to the running, they took the shoe and adapted it to the runner.” 
—Irene Davis
 
Cushioned running shoes, heel striking and impact forces [29:30]
Impact forces

Studies have shown that people create greater landing force in the HOKA shoe
The increased cushioning gives a false sense of security that encourages a harder landing

Heel vs. forefoot striking

A study has shown that the heel has a relatively low pain threshold that doesn’t extend far beyond the level of force generated during walking—suggesting that we have evolved to be forefoot strikers
Other studies have shown that it is footwear that encouraged many of us to become heel strikers

Lieberman et al., 2010
Lieberman et al., 2015


Most barefoot runners are forefoot strikers (even Atlas the robot runs with a forefoot strike)
Irene believes that we are adapted to be forefoot strikers and that this is why we have a long Achilles tendon
An advantage of heel striking is that it allows for a longer stride and therefore greater speed, and on softer surfaces, this might be reasonable


Figure 2. Impact forces from heel striking versus forefoot striking. Image credit: researchgate.net
 
Shin splints [33:45]

One of the most common injuries that runners have when they first start running is an “overuse” injury called shin splints
Shin splints manifest as pain in the front of the lower leg
The primary muscle where this occurs, the tibialis anterior, is much smaller than the muscles in the back of the lower leg
The tibialis anterior concentrically lifts the forefoot towards the knee and eccentrically controls the lowering of the forefoot towards the ground
Because of the smaller size, the tibialis anterior is more prone to the fatigue and overuse that can result in shin splints

“If you just look at the shape of the human lower leg, it’s designed to carry more load in the back than in the front.” 
—Peter Attia
 
How heel strike patterns promotes knee stress through rate of loading [35:30]

A forefoot strike allows for the calf and the motion of the foot to absorb some of the impact force and also allows the transition of force from the foot to the knee to occur gradually
With a heel strike, more of the impact force goes directly to the knee, and the force is transferred more rapidly
Studies have shown higher rates of force transfer to be associated with running injuries

Irene’s approach with patients in the clinic:

When people that come in with injuries will be habituated to foot orthotics and/or habituated to standard shoes
Irene’s goal is to get the person running closer to the way we evolve to move and therefore lessening the risk for injury

“We really try to get people back into shoes that allow their feet to do what they were adapted to do and to run in a pattern that is closer to our evolutionary legacy.” —Irene Davis
Does Irene believe that there are certain people who just shouldn’t be running?

“I believe that running is an activity of daily living. People talk about running being a skill, I don’t think it is. We learn to run on our own.”
Very few exceptions — e.g., huge leg length discrepancy that is really going to abnormally load, extreme foot deformities, etc.
But when you look at the normal distribution of people, most people can run

 
The critical importance of exercise [42:15]
Trailer for an interesting documentary: The Motivation Factor 
The documentary follows a high school boot camp-style fitness program:

In 1955, a Marine by the name of Stan LeProtti started a program at a high school in Carmichael, California in which every kid went through a military-type boot camp
The program was partly driven by motivation – each advancing level of fitness was associated with a different color of shorts — Everyone started out with white shorts and could then progress to different colors representing more advanced fitness levels

How the results of this program symbolize Irene’s thoughts on the innate human ability to run

All of the kids in this program ended fit and looking like they were in the military
Irene believes that all of these kids, who now range from approximately 55-80 years old, would still be capable of running well today. 
She believes that basic movement skill fosters proper running mechanics and that the lack of such skill is the reason why so many people today have improper running mechanics
But you do need to be fit to run because being fit implies development of the motor control needed to run properly

“I think everyone who has a pretty normally intact neuromuscular system can run. But to answer your question, should that teenager who’s overweight and has been doing video games go out and run? Probably not.”
 
Impact forces and injury potential [45:45]
Based on Irene’s work with runners on a treadmill equipped with a force plate:

Heel striking leads to a more rapid rate of vertical force development
Forefoot striking in minimalist shoes decreases the rate of force development

 
How shoe cushioning alters impact forces despite forefoot striking [49:00]
Forefoot striking in cushioned shoes has unwanted effects:

It promotes landing with more plantar flexion (forefoot more pointed towards ground), which exposes the Achilles tendon to greater stress
It also promotes landing on the outside of the foot, which causes an increase in lateral forces. This tends to result in problems in both the Achilles and peroneal tendons

Considerations for shoe selection

Forefoot striking should be done in minimalist shoes
People who choose to remain heel strikers should wear cushioned shoes

 
An overview of minimalist shoes [52:30]
“When I talk about minimal, I’m talking about a shoe you can roll up and put in your pocket.” 
—Irene Davis

Figure 3. Cushioned versus minimalist shoes. Image credit: vivobarefoot.com

Three brands of minimalist shoes that you can roll up and put in your pocket:

Vivobarefoot
Xero
Inov-8


The Vibram lawsuit turned people away from minimalist shoes, leading most companies to add more substance to their minimalist shoes
There are now a number of “partial” minimalist shoes, as Irene calls them, which tend to have cushioning, a heel-to-toe drop, and sometimes arch support

Examples of shoes that fall into this category include Nike Free and New Balance Minimus
A major problem with these shoes is that they still encourage people to heel strike, but with less cushion

In one study, partial minimal shoes were associated with twice as much injuries as fully minimalist shoes
People who run in these shoes should learn to forefoot strike with a minimalist shoe, and if they do not want to, Irene suggests that they use fully cushioned shoes and replace them every 300-500 miles



 
Irene’s protocol for transitioning people out of orthotics [58:45]
Irene’s neck brace example

Wearing a neck brace for life will leave your neck muscles weak and unable to hold your head up
Wearing orthotics will have as similar effect on the 10 muscles in the arch of your foot

A gradual approach, over the course of 2-3 weeks

Irene has people initially keep their orthotics with them and gradually increase time without them – for example, the first half mile of a three-mile walk
Once someone can regularly walk comfortably without orthotics, she has them transition to minimalist shoes
A study led by Sarah Ridge from BYU has shown simply walking in minimalist shoes to be as effective as a dedicated foot-strengthening program

 
Transitioning to minimalist shoes and a forefoot strike [1:05:30]

It’s a one to three month process, depending on age 
Focus spans to include foot, hip, and knee function
Activities like hopping, lunging, and jumping rope are included to develop dynamic movement skill
Only after basic movement function has been developed does treadmill training start
Someone should be able to handle a 30-minute brisk walk with forefoot strike and minimalist shoes before starting on a treadmill. Otherwise, consequences include plantar fasciitis and metatarsal stress fracture 

 
Foot muscle volume, minimalist shoes, and orthotics [1:07:00]

Irene’s team did a study (Chen et al., 2016) showing that cross sectional volume of foot muscles is larger in people who run with minimalist shoes
Another study has shown that people who start wearing orthotics experience a decrease in foot muscle volume

 
The recognition of the importance of foot strength in podiatry [1:09:45]

Recently published physical therapy guidelines for plantar fasciitis include orthotics and other approaches, but neglect to include strengthening
In contrast, guidelines for any other part of the body do include strengthening
Despite this, Irene’s experience is that podiatrists are becoming increasingly interested in using exercise and movement training instead of orthotics

 
Minimalist shoes across the lifespan—from children to adults [1:12:30]

Irene believes minimalist shoes are important for kids so that their feet develop properly
Since we lose muscle power with age, and in the feet and lower extremities first, Irene also believes that transitioning to minimalist shoes is important for adults
Courses/programs related to training forefoot strike: Pose Method & ChiRunning

“It’s about getting people into shoes that let their feet do what they’re supposed to do.”
 
Why learning to forefoot strike on soft surfaces is not the best approach [1:20:00]

Running barefoot has the benefit of maximizing sensory input from ground contact
Running on grass barefoot is not a good idea because you may not see things that will injure your foot
Soft surfaces in general will encourage more stiffness throughout the body
In contrast, harder surfaces will encourage a softer landing

Studies that have shown softer running surfaces to encourage greater leg stiffness while running:

Running in the real world: adjusting leg stiffness for different surfaces 
Runners adjust leg stiffness for their first step on a new running surface 

 
Knee valgus and factors related to knee injury [1:21:45]
Injuries are multifactorial

Poor movement pattern is not always the cause. While someone with poor movement will likely be injured more quickly, someone with good movement still has increased injury risk if their dose of movement is too high
Poor movement can manifest as injury in different ways – for example, knee valgus might cause knee pain, but it may instead cause hip pain

Causes of injury and knee valgus

Irene’s running injury clinic has worked with more than 700 people
The factors most often found in association with injury are high impact forces and poor alignment
Knee valgus is the most common manifestation of poor alignment
Instability of foot muscles, or the “foot core” as she calls it, is a cause of knee valgus


Figure 4. Knee valgus and associated movements. Image credit: researchgate.net
 
IT band syndrome [1:28:30]

The iliotibial band (or IT band for short) connects the tensor fasciae latae to the lateral (outside) part of the tibia at the knee
Irene’s group has done both prospective and retrospective studies on people with history of IT band syndrome, and in both cases found greater inward angulation of the thigh, which stretches the IT band
Inward rotation of the tibia was also found in these studies, which is associated with pronation (rolling in) of the foot, also stretches the IT band
Based on the above mechanisms, IT band syndrome can originate from the hip or the foot
Peter was able to eliminate his IT band pain through eccentric strengthening of his gluteus medius

 
Physics and ground reaction forces [1:33:15]

Ground reaction forces are an example of Newton’s third law of physics (for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction)
For example, when you push against the ground, because of the massive size of earth, the ground will not move. The reaction is therefore translated into pushing yourself away from the ground rather than pushing the ground away.
As these reaction forces are transferred through joints, the compress the joint in the process, which is how the force within the joint ends up being greater than the original amount of force being applied because of the internal moment arm in the joint and because of other stabilizing muscles contracting across the other side of the joint


Figure 5. Ground reaction forces during different stages of gait. Image credit: mass4d.com
 
Irene’s approach to retraining a runner’s gait [1:36:00]
“Mechanics is something that’s very modifiable, and for a long time people did not believe that.”
 —Irene Davis
Gait retraining in Irene’s clinic

Irene’s ideas of being able to retrain gait in runners was met with skepticism during the early years of her career
It is now known that gait can be reprogrammed
Gait retraining requires a lot of practice, however. It is not easy to retrain a movement pattern that has been engrained for decades
Feedback is helpful, but must eventually be faded out
In Irene’s lab, the process involves an average of two months spent working on gait, four weeks of gait training on the treadmill, and then 10 weeks of supervised incremental increases in running

The disconnect between prevention and health insurance

The logical approach would be a proactive retraining of gait to prevent injury
However, insurance only covers gait retraining after injury
Because of this, 100% of the gait retraining Irene does is with people who have already been injured
The example Peter gives to demonstrate the misguided approach taken by insurance companies here is that treating type 2 diabetes costs $7,000 to $12,000 per year compared to spending about $500 per year to prevent someone from ever getting the disease

Evidence that gait retraining works over the long term
One of Irene’s former postdocs did a study involving 320 novice runners:

Half of the runners were trained on a treadmill to soften their impact (probably by inadvertently learning to forefoot strike)
A year later, there was a 62% decrease in injuries

Similarly, a retrospective study by Dan Lieberman on the Harvard track team found that forefoot strikers had half of the chronic injuries as heel strikers
 
Case study—How the transition to minimalist shoes decreased injury and improved performance [1:42:15]

A physician in a closed Christian community, inspired by the book Born to Run, resolved his own foot problems by running barefoot and in minimalist shoes
He gradually started recommending it to members of the community’s track team who had season-ending injuries and weren’t responding to standard of care
Eventually, 80% of the community was wearing minimalist shoes, and referrals to podiatrists decreased as use of minimalist shoes increased
The community’s cross country team ended up completing a season with no injuries and winning their division. They were bumped up to the next division, where they also did well, possibly finishing as high as second

 
Importance of proper movement patterns and the negative influence of our modern environment [1:45:30]

Peter and Irene believe that frequent sitting and wearing of shoes present a major challenge for maintaining proper movement in today’s society
Irene suggests that gym class in schools should be every day and should involve more demanding movement including calisthenics

By the time kids are 12 to 17 years old, a report from the National Adolescent and Young Adult Health Information Center shows about 31% of them have at least one chronic condition
Irene also believes that sport specificity presents similar problems and that kids should be encouraged to play multiple sports
